perturbation.original_text: This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ and ABW and all of their subsidiaries and related companies.
perturbation.changed_text: This amendment to Section 2 (titled "Term"), Part B of the Co-Branding Agreement is made effective December 9, 1996 by and between PC Quote, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. (hereinafter referred to as "ABW"), who are also the parties contracted in the aforementioned Co-Branding Agreement. This Amendment shall apply to said PCQ and ABW. This agreement does not grant rights to subsidiaries or related companies.
perturbation.explanation: By explicitly denying rights to subsidiaries and related companies, the modified text omits potential liabilities and responsibilities typically associated with parent companies and subsidiaries, potentially violating laws related to corporate liability and piercing the corporate veil. This is a legal contradiction, because generally a contract between a parent company should apply to the activities of the subsidiary.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Corporate Liability Law, Piercing the Corporate Veil Doctrine

perturbation.original_text:
AGREED TO BY:

/s/ Steven Malin /s/ Howard Meltzer - -------------------------- --------------------------------- A.B. Watley, Inc. PC Quote, Inc. Mr. Steven Malin Mr. Howard Meltzer Director President Date:  12/5/96 Date:   12/12/96      -------------- ----------------
perturbation.changed_text:
AGREED TO BY:

/s/ Steven Malin /s/ Howard Meltzer - -------------------------- --------------------------------- A.B. Watley, Inc. PC Quote, Inc. Mr. Steven Malin Mr. Howard Meltzer Director President Date:  12/5/96
perturbation.explanation: By removing the date on one of the signatures, the enforceability of the contract is brought into question because there is no verifiable evidence of the date that the president of PC Quote, Inc. agreed to the contract. This could violate laws or regulations requiring that legal contracts must contain a date.
